SHORTPROSE.P: PJ is best remembered for the poem The Song My Paddle Sings, published in 1892, which has been memorized by generations of Canadian school children, but she also wrote short stories and journalism, and recorded the legends of the Squamish people. Her writing struggles to bring together the two world views, British and Native, with which she was acquainted, and her literary persona straddles the figures of the New Woman and the emergent Canadian author. Poet Glenn Wilmott, citing critic Terry Goldie, advises anyone who wants to learn something about the history and historicity of literary value, go to this poet.44

CHRONPROSE.PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY: PJ published her first poem, My Little Jean, apparently in the periodical Gems of Poetry; but no verification has been made to date.

SHORTPROSE.P: Biographer Betty Keller believes that the poem was first penned in 1879 and addressed to PJ's close friend Jean Morton, from the Brantford Collegiate Institute, PJ's high school. Biographers Gerson and Strong-Boag find evidence of its publication history in the History of the County of Brant but have been unable actually to locate the poem in Gems of Poetry, a periodical not associated with the high school. The first poem they are able to find in that journal appeared in August 1884, entitled The Rift. PJ signed it with the pseudonym Margaret Rox. She continued in the following years to publish poems in Gems of Poetry, The Week (the most prestigious literary and intellectual journal in Canada at the time), and Saturday Night.36277, 219

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ's poem The Sea Queen, published this day in The Week, attracted the attention of its former editor, Charles G. D. Roberts; they began to correspond.

P.RRECOGNITIONS: PJ did not meet Roberts in person until the summer of 1895, when he presented her with a manuscript copy of his book Songs of the Common Day and the pen he used to write it.

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: Between the two surrenders which ended the North West Rebellion (that of Poundmaker on 26 May and that of Big Bear on 2 July), PJ published in The Week her poem A Cry from an Indian Wife.

SHORTPROSE.P: This is the poem she read at a Toronto literary evening in 1892 which is said to have launched her performing career. It is the first poem in which she engages with hybridity, a theme that she would continue to explore with mixed-race heroines such as Christine in Red Girl's Reasoning.16, 149

The poem, presented as a dramatic monologue, figures the nation of Canada as a hybrid of two founding peoples. It alternates support for Anglo-European Canadians and dispossessed natives, while overlooking the French. It ends, however, with a clear, though resentfully equivocating, declaration of Native rights:
Go forth, nor bend to greed of white men's hands,
By right, by birth we Indians own these lands,
Though starved, crushed, plundered lies our nation low . . .
Perhaps the white man's God has willed it so.18149

P.TINTERTEXTUALITY: Particularly in its foregrounding of religion in its attack on racial inequality, this poem seems indebted to Elizabeth Barrett Browning's The Runaway Slave at Pilgrim's Point.

P.RRESPONSES: One of the early responses to the work addressed PJ as the dark daughter of the forest and admonished her that men must work and women must weep.46

PSUBMISSIONSREJECTIONS.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published In the Shadows, a canoeing poem, in The Week after it had been rejected by her mother's cousin William Dean Howells, then editor at Harper's.

SHORTPROSE.P: It re-appeared later in the Athenæum. PJ was particularly annoyed that her own relation had responded negatively to her work. Howells allegedly boasted of his connection to the Johnson family (as exotics) while he was the US consul in Venice, although it is not clear that PJ knew about this.55

This poem exhibits what was to become a recurrent theme for her: the sensuality of canoeing and of the outdoors. She writes evocatively of the
. . . perfume of some burning
Far-off brushwood, ever turning
To exhale
All its smoky fragrance dying,
In the arms of evening lying,
Where I sail.83-4

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: The Globe published an interview between PJ and Brantford writer Sara Jeannette Duncan, who was just one year the elder of the two.

SHORTPROSE.P: Duncan, using the pseudonym Garth Grafton, mentioned knowing PJ for some time and focused on her physical attributes and Mohawk ancestry. The publicity which resulted from the interview brought Johnson wider attention.49-50

Critics Carole Gerson and Veronica Strong-Boag argue that during this period PJ contributed significantly to the remarkable upsurge of Canadian literary activity that occurred during an era of fervent cultural and political nationalism on both sides of the Atlantic. From about 1885 onward, PJ joined a critical mass of writers who were constructing a distinct national identity for former colonies struggling towards collective consciousness.100-1

CHRONPROSE.RRECOGNITIONS: Two of PJ's poems were chosen for the influential Canadian anthology Songs of the Great Dominion, edited by W. D. Lighthall.

SHORTPROSE.P: This helped to establish her as a key figure in English-Canadian literature. The two poems chosen were In the Shadows and At The Ferry (about the Grand River). Wider circulation resulted when her poetry was included in an 1893 anthology meant for school use, J. E. Wetherell's Later Canadian Poems. It is possible that PJ herself persuaded Wetherell to add women poets to the edition.101, 119

CHRONPROSE.PPERFORMANCE: PJ read A Cry from an Indian Wife at Frank Yeigh's Canadian Literature Evening in Toronto; it was a huge success and launched her performance career.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Also read that night was poetry by Agnes Maule Machar and Wilfrid Campbell. PJ's encore piece was As Red Men Die, based on a legend about a Mohawk man who chooses death on live coals instead of slavery. This was not her first performance: she had given public readings before in Brantford, but Yeigh, her first manager, later claimed this as the originating moment of her public career.
Yeigh claimed that he persuaded her to dress that night in Indian togs while many others, including newspaper reports of the time, remember her in a simple grey gown. She did not begin wearing native clothing until the fall of 1893. Her success was such that follow-up recitals were scheduled for the next week and featured a new work: The Song My Paddle Sings.57-62102-3

P.RRESPONSES: In a review of the evening, a Toronto Globe critic misread Johnson's poem as a lament for a disappearing race: it was like the voice of the nations who once possessed this country, who have wasted away before our civilization, speaking through this cultured, gifted, soft-voiced descendant.150

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: PJ's recitals were noticed in the New York Times (as full of dramatic power and tragic motive) and the New York Sun (as the work of perhaps the most unique figure in the literary world on this continent).

PPERIODICALPUBLICATION.RBESTKNOWNWORK: PJ first published her best-known poem, The Song My Paddle Sings, in Saturday Night.

SHORTPROSE.P:
The poem is written in the first person (thereby lending itself to performance), but also combines the paddler and her canoe into a we, challenging male narratives which see the landscape as something to be conquered. Critics Gerson and Strong Boag identify the canoe as a Canadian equivalent to the iconographic bicycle of the New Woman. Unlike a bicycle, a canoe can be a site of sexual encounters, as implied in other verses by PJ. In this poem, however, the erotic connection is between the canoeist and nature. For example, the narrator and canoeist speaks of courting the west wind:
I stow the sail, unship the mast:
I wooed you long but my wooing's past;
My paddle will lull you into rest.
O! Drowsy wind of the drowsy west . . . .32
A description of rapids brings the poem to a climax before returning to the gentle rhythms of the beginning, with A fir tree rocking its lullaby.34153-4

CHRONPROSE.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: PJ's first collection of poetry, The White Wampum, was published by John Lane in London.

PRELATIONSWITHPUBLISHER.PSUBMISSIONSREJECTIONS: The association with Lane was the outcome of PJ's visit to London. She secured him as her publisher after a recommendation from critic Clement Scott, and positive responses to her work by John Davidson and Percy White.

P.PRARITIESFEATURESDECORATIONS: The cover was reddish brown with a design by E. H. New featuring a hatchet and wampum belt over Johnson's Mohawk name.

P.RRESPONSES: Reviews for this work were kind in Canada—The Week wrote glowing comments, for example—but mixed in Britain. A Guardian reviewer, who seemingly missed the point that PJ was half-Mohawk, suggested that the idea of posing as an Indian bard cannot be counted among her happiest inspirations.101-2

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ later mused philosophically about rejection and praise: [p]oems are our brain children—we love them too much to have them treated badly. Then, too, what will please one critic will not, with his line of thought, please another.60

One poem that was not published was His Sister's Son, although it appeared frequently on her recital program during the mid-1890s. It dealt with the effect of residential schools on uprooted native children, and one stanza preserved by a journalist shows it to be strongly condemnatory. Only this one stanza survives.148

TINTERTEXTUALITY.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ's The Corn-Husker, a direct poetic response to Duncan Campbell Scott's poems Onandaga Madonna and Watkewenies, appeared in Harper's Weekly.

SHORTPROSE.P: Scott's characters were figured as members of a disappearing race. One poem associates Indian women with promiscuity and the other associates Indian men with violence. PJ answers his implications with carefully chosen wording when she blames the demise of First Nations' cultures on might's injustice.95 After the appearance of this poem, PJ turned from poetry to prose as a more effective vehicle for Native advocacy.151
Scott also answered Johnson in his own poetry. Critics Gerson and Strong-Boag find echoes of her dramatic poem Ojistoh in his work At Gull Lake: 1810.121

CHRONPROSE.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: PJ published a collection of poems, Canadian Born, with Morang in Toronto.

SHORTPROSE.P: It was a slim volume with a light blue cover and featured a picture of PJ in native costume. An inscription addressed the book to anyone Canadian born, whether he be my paleface compatriot who has given to me his right hand of good fellowship . . . or whether he be that dear Red brother of whatsoever tribe or Province.179 The title poem was first performed around 1897. The collection met with negative critical response.178197

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ's Flint and Feather, another collection of poetry, was published.

SHORTPROSE.P: This was revised and enlarged in 1913, and again, as Flint and Feather: The Complete Poems of E. Pauline Johnson, in 1917. A 1921 edition has been made available online, and a 1997 edition appeared in the Iroquois Reprints series.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ won first prize for a campaign song, The Good Old N. P., written to extol the virtues of the National Policy League, which opposed free trade.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ also wrote jingles used by the Summerland Development Company and by the Canadian Manufacturers' Association at a banquet in Brantford.210196

PPERIODICALPUBLICATION.RRECOGNITIONS: PJ's short story Red Girl's Reasoning was published in Dominion Illustrated after winning first prize for fiction in their contest the previous year.

BIBCIT.PLACEHOLDER: Ruoff, Justice for Indians and Women, 252

SHORTPROSE.P: This story features a mixed-race heroine named Christine Robinson, daughter of a happily married Native mother and trader father, who falls in love with a white boy from the city. She eventually marries the city boy, Charles McDonald, who has earned respect from the native community, and they move to a city. Their marriage ends after a party where Christine tells a group of listeners that her parents were married by Indian rites. Horrified, Charles accuses her of disgracing him by announcing, in effect, her illegitimacy. This provokes Christine to discount her own marriage: Why should I recognize the rites of your nation when you do not acknowledge the rites of mine?253 Though she still loves her husband, she leaves him to go live in a small town where she supports herself doing embroidery and plain sewing. Even after Charles begs her to come back, Christine coolly answers that neither church, nor law . . . nor even love can make a slave of a red girl.253

PJ considered turning Red Girl's Reasoning, one of her most popular stories, into a play, but little came of this idea.
Keller reports that it developed into a playlet performed at recitals.70 Critic LaVonne Brown Ruoff summarizes the story as being about the legitimacy of tribal ceremonies for linking native women and white men, and the independence of native women. She argues that the dissolution of marriage was unusual in a romance written at this time and reads it, in part, as a cautionary tale about white men who seem sympathetic to native ways but are not.252-3
The story was later collected in The Moccasin Maker.

HEADING.TITLE: As It Was in the Beginning

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published in Saturday Night the short story As It Was in the Beginning, which explores issues of racial intolerance.

SHORTPROSE.P: As It Was in the Beginning features a Cree and French heroine, Esther, who kills her white lover after he is dissuaded from marrying her by his uncle, a priest named Father Paul. The story begins with Esther's removal to a residential school run by Father Paul where she experiences culture shock mitigated only by her friendship with Lawrence, who later wishes to marry her. The priest warns Lawrence that you can never tell what lurks in a caged animal that has once been wild.253 The speech is overheard by Esther, who then arranges to kill her lover with an arrowhead tipped with snake venom.253-4

Critic LaVonne Brown Ruoff notes that unlike Christine in Red Girl's Reasoning, Esther does not confront her oppressors with arguments or verbal jousting. Her response is not negotiation or protest but violence, as if she has given up the hope of peaceful resolution between Natives and Anglo-Europeans.254

On 23 May 1904 PJ and McRaye stopped in Edmonton, Alberta, for the last of the winter snow. While there, PJ watched as a tired dog team made its way into town, and listened as the sled kept scraping over the bare ground. This event inspired her short story The Haunting Thaw.200

P.PMOTIVES: PJ looked at the healthy market for boys' stories (in periodicals such as The Boys' World) and began spinning tales of brave Mounties, trappers, and cowboys battling blizzards, raging torrents, and ravening beasts in the Canadian wilderness.205

SHORTPROSE.P: Some of the stories, such as The Shagganappi and Little Wolf-Willow, featured Native pupils to point up intolerance in Canadian classrooms. Little Wolf-Willow, who stands up to a principal at a residential school, is rewarded later in the story with a position of importance and trust from all sides.197

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Canadian Women's Press Club issued two posthumous collections of stories by PJ: The Shagganappi (reprinted from The Boys' World) and The Moccasin Maker (from Mother's Magazine).

CHRONPROSE.PSUBMISSIONSREJECTIONS: The editor of Mother's Magazine solicited a Dominion Day Mother's Story from PJ, and paid her $17.64 for Her Dominion—A Story of 1867, and Canada's Confederation.

SHORTPROSE.P: The story centres on the mother of one of the Fathers of Confederation. She is shown inventing the term confederation, which her son then appropriates, shifting its sense away from the mothering and towards the fathering of a nation.72-3
For this market PJ prepared not only short stories but non-fiction. From January 1908 she published a series of articles in Mother's Magazine on topics of interest to mothers.227

P.PLITERARYSCHOOLS: PJ wrote extensively on women's sporting life, as was appropriate for a New Woman.
P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: In publications such as Saturday Night, the Weekly Detroit Free Press, and Outing, she advocated canoeing, hockey, and camping as healthy activities for women.

TITLE.REG: A Strong Race Opinion: On the Indian Girl in Modern Fiction

HEADING.TITLE: The Indian Girl in Modern Fiction

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published in the Toronto Sunday Globe a prescient piece of literary criticism entitled A Strong Race Opinion: On the Indian Girl in Modern Fiction.

SHORTPROSE.P: The essay questions why Native women are portrayed by a single stereotype in the literature of the time, as dog-like, fawn-like, crouching, fire-eyed [and] submissive.188 In particular, PJ criticizes the novel An Algonquin Maiden by G. Mercer Adam and A. Ethelwyn Wetherald.187

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published Iroquois of the Grand River in Harper's Weekly.

P.PRARITIESFEATURESDECORATIONS: The illustrations for this article were by A. H. H. Heming, who depicted PJ's brother Allen in Indian costume with a ring in his nose.

SHORTPROSE.P: PJ's language is plain and direct. Other articles about Iroquois culture, such as A Glimpse at the Grand River Indians, are condescending in tone to her pagan subjects.111-12 A series of articles for Mother's Magazine in 1908 characterised Iroquois women as possessing beautiful old-fashioned womanliness; for them the grace of motherhood is a primitive glory.115 This portrayal did little to represent such women as fully realized individuals.

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published A Pagan in St. Paul's, the most successful of three articles by her which appeared in London's Daily Express this summer.

SHORTPROSE.P: The other two articles were The Lodge of the Law-Makers and The Silent News-Carrier.

P.TPLOT: A Pagan in St. Paul's describes a Native person who is drawn into the crowd of worshippers at St Paul's Cathedral in Aldermanbury, London, where he discerns no real difference between Native and British religious views.

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published a travel story in Toronto Saturday Night, retelling her adventures on the Cariboo Road in British Columbia.

TINTERTEXTUALITY.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: PJ published in Mother's Magazine a story based on the Squamish legends told to her by Chief Joe Capilano; many more followed in 1910.

P.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: The publication of these legends, in the Vancouver Province for example, provoked criticism.
P.RRESPONSES: PJ was accused of misunderstanding Chief Joe's Chinook language and his stories, though Keller suggests that the results of her interpretations were not deliberate falsifications, but rather a result of her inability to give a direct translation because she reacted mainly to the dramatic parts of any tale.250 It was, oddly enough, one of her few introductions to the oral tradition of First Nations people, and her re-tellings mediated between oral and literary traditions of story-telling.177 Critics Gerson and Strong-Boag suggest these writings performed significant cultural work regarding local White/Native relations.

SHORTPROSE.P: When PJ was unable to continue writing because cancer was sending shooting pains down her arm, Vancouver Province editor Lionel Makovski transcribed her stories as she dictated them from her couch. In this way, the legends continued to find their way into print during the summer of 1910.251-2

Sensing that she needed money, PJ's friends devised a scheme to raise funds and publish the legends, with all profits to go to her. The Women's Canadian Club held a recital in Vancouver's Pender Auditorium featuring, among other entertainments, Isabel Ecclestone MacKay reading poetry.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: PJ's controversial versions of Capilano legends were published as Legends of Vancouver, not as she wished under the title Legends of the Capilanos.

P.PEARNINGS: She received an influx of money from it, and future editions provided enough to assist her with her medical expenses.

SHORTPROSE.P: Critical reception of PJ's writing has been uneven, ranging from outright dismissals to celebrations. These responses clearly illuminate the preoccupations of critics, many of whom were primarily interested in constructing narrow versions of Canadian literary history. PJ and her writings were excluded from these exercises in canon formation on several counts: she was a woman, a Mohawk, and her focus on romantic love did not fit into the literary models of nation building favoured by Canadian modernists. Although a commemorative stamp was issued in her honour in 1961, dominant critical opinion of her at that time was almost thoroughly dismissive. Earle Birney and Robertson Davies, for example, described her poetry as unimportant and shallow.130

P.RSHEINFLUENCED: PJ's legacy is reworked more recently in Joan Crate's poem cycle Pale as Real Ladies, published in 1989. Although the treatment is generally a sympathetic one, the poet seems to conclude that PJ sold out by capitalizing on her Native background to pander to audiences.

P.RFICTIONALIZATION: In the 1970s, the nature of PJ's legacy was subjected to artistic scrutiny in two theatre productions. Theatre Passe Muraille mounted Pauline in 1972 and Studio Lab produced Pauline Johnson in 1975. A third play, by Betty Donaldson, was staged in Calgary in 1993.

P.RRESPONSES: As recently as 1999, PJ's artistic legacy was still dismissed in some quarters. In a televised biography produced that year for Canada's History Channel, host Patrick Watson referred scornfully to The Song My Paddle Sings.

RRESPONSES.RSHEINFLUENCED: On the other hand, Mohawk writer Beth Brant claims PJ as the originator of a movement that has proved unstoppable in its momentum—the movement of First Nations women to write down our stories.134131

P.RRECOGNITIONS: PJ's life was later celebrated by the release of a commemorative stamp in the centennial year of her birth. A secondary school in Brantford, Ontario, and an elementary school in Vancouver are named in her honour.
